awd_titl_txt: INSPIRE: Expanding Open Innovation Methods to Complex Engineered Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
This Integrated NSF Support Promoting Interdisciplinary Research and Education (INSPIRE) project is jointly funded by the Systems Science program in the Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation (CMMI) Division in the Engineering Directorate, by the Science of Science and Innovation Policy in the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities in the Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences Directorate, and by the Office of Integrative Activities.  The America COMPETES Act embodies a presidential directive for federal agencies to "spur innovation, solve tough problems, and advance their core missions" through an expanded use of open innovation methods. Open innovation describes an approach that solicits external input through for example, prizes, challenges and crowdsourcing. Despite the enormous promise of the approach, current successes are limited to a small subset of the potential applications implied in the vision. The theory generated through this award will provide the scientific basis for expanding the implementation of open methods to increasingly complex problems, by identifying the parts of problems most amenable to open methods. This has implications for how agencies solicit Research and Development (R&D) and how firms organize their research enterprise and incentivize their employees. It will provide a path to sustained American Competitiveness. In addition, an increased use of open innovation explicitly breaks down barriers to participation. It opens STEM for everyone; creating pathways, particularly for resource-constrained schools, to engage students in real-world problem solving.

This award supports fundamental research to generate knowledge about how open innovation methods can be made applicable to complex systems through appropriate upfront decomposition. Specifically it will address two questions: (1) How does the extent of problem decomposition effect a) the ability for external solvers to contribute and b) the quality of solutions received? And: (2) How can organizations capture the value of open innovation methods and overcome adoption challenges? Addressing each question builds a necessary scientific basis for the complex phenomenon of open innovation policy and requires a novel integration of theory and methods from multiple disciplines. With respect to question (1), heuristics for how to best decompose a given system to leverage external contributions will be identified based on a simulation model and a series of field experiments. The theoretical basis will draw on organization design, systems engineering, economics, and the motivations of designers. Question (2) will be addressed through an in-depth longitudinal study of NASA?s ongoing experiment deploying open innovation methods within its existing R&D process. Field observations of how internal R&D experts respond to their changing identity from "problem solver" to "solution seeker" will be synthesized to explain how this necessary transition can be mitigated without losing internal talent. Theoretically, question 2 challenges longstanding assumptions about the optimal way to organize for innovation. This research will transform current practices in terms of how innovation is organized.

por.por_cntn:
The America COMPETES Act embodies a presidential directive for federal agencies to ?spur innovation, solve tough problems, and advance their core missions? through an expanded use of open innovation methods. Despite a growing arsenal of success stories, to date, open innovation (OI) tools have only been used on a relatively narrow subset of complex problem types and there remains a strong skepticism among engineerings as to whether ?open? can be applied to their physically integral system design problems.

To that end, this INSPIRE project aimed to generate new knowledge about how, and under what conditions, OI can be leveraged to solve complex systems problems. Specifically, it focused on understanding how choices made in upfront problem formulation affected the "crowd" in terms of who showed interest and capacity to solve challenge problems. The research was conducted using a mixed methods approach, including 1) a qualitative study of the formulation processes within a seeking organization; 2) a large-scale field experiment that manipulated the problem formulation and observed the impact it had on the make-up of the crowd of solvers and the solutions they submitted; and 3) theoretical studies exploring the socio-technical linkages between system architecture and non-domain, non-expert solving. All work was conducted in close collaboration with NASA experts.

Combined, the research thrusts generated several important contributions. First the results shed light on differences between who in the "crowd" shows interest in solving open innovation challenges, and the subset capable of providing high quality solutions. This difference was examined in terms of the demographics, prior training, experience, and motivations, and found that broadcast search - the way OI methods attract solvers - indeed broadens the population of potential solvers, though to different extents depending on the dimension. For example, OI attracts diverse knowledge perspectives but did not improve the proportion of female solvers in our sample. The impact of this diversity varies depending on the complexity and framing of the challenge problem, which creates a lever for meeting policy goals related to participatory government and increasing inclusion and diversity.

Second, we expand the conception of how open solving contributes to the design process. While most prior work has focused on the performance of winning solutions, by studying the population of solutions and the design justifications they included, we discovered several other important features of what the crowd can contribute. Particularly in the context of complex challenge problems, the crowd generated many novel design concepts and solving approaches, suggesting that OI can serve an important function during the conceptual design phase, preceding work by internal experts.

Third, we found a strong influence between the way the problem was formulated and how the crowd solved. This is more than a matter of investing more effort translating the problem so that it is accessible by a broader audience. We articulated different modes of formulation, ranging from decomposing to de-contextualizing and re-contextualizing. In the latter categories the problem is reframed to connect with pre-identified external experts from other disciplines. These processes can effectively tap into distant experts and provide solutions to stubborn problems. Importantly, we identified core tensions between the potential for novel solutions and the likelihood of receiving useful ones. This has important implications for where seeking organizations choose to spend their effort in the solving process.

Fourth, to navigate this tension we proposed an approach to formulation that emphasizes hybrid solving. Specifically, breaking up complex problems in such a way to separate the aspects that are best solved by internal experts, and those that can benefit from the core OI solving mechanisms. We demonstrated the feasibility of these ideas in an abstract model and corroborated the ideas with data from the field experiment.  This opens the path for a mode of systems architecting that is solver aware.

Finally, the data generated through the field experiment is itself a contribution. We have only begun to exploit its richness and are working to share as much of it as feasible. It has the potential to shed light on questions as diverse as the motivations and capacities of gig workers (through the solver data) and exploring multiple design features including novelty, feasibility, and complexity (through the solution data).

Throughout the project the research team made dissemination a core part of the work. We joined the conversation of the federal prizes and challenges community, leading workshops and contributing to guidelines. We shared our insights with broader audiences through platforms like SXSWi, podcasts, contributions to a forthcoming National Academies Study, a module in a Harvard Online course. In addition, this project provided unique training experience to several grad students and a postdoctoral scientist, merging research with challenge implementation in collaboration with NASA. Moreover, as an INSPIRE project the research team brought together unusually distant disciplinary collaboration which created a rich (and challenging) experience in cross-disciplinary communication and theory-building.
